> The only way to really check some SQL code is to put it through an SQL
> parser (ie a DB) and check it retrieves what you think it retrieves.
> I never do this this myself as most of the SQL I have to deal with just
> basic CRUD operations.
> I guess what we really need here is a small , in memory database that can be
> run as part of a test case. That is, the setUp() starts the the DB itself.
 
> Anyone know of such a thing? or want to write one?

I've used "HyperSonic SQL" in a similar fashion in the past and it worked
very well.  It uses the filesystem for the data, I don't know if you can
have it work in memory only.  You're right that it would be very slick to
test this way.  Of course, SQL seems to be highly non-portable but this
would be one way of attempting to find a common subset.  Looks like it
does support in-memory databases, too:
http://hsqldb.sourceforge.net/

Later,
	Dale
